output.rationale: This appears to be an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 (along with PM10) exposure and respiratory hospital admissions using distributed lag non-linear models, which is consistent with time-series analysis. The study reports quantitative associations between PM2.5 and respiratory disease hospitalizations (asthma and COPD) with statistical significance mentioned. While the study has a COVID-19 context comparing two time periods, the core analysis meets inclusion criteria for exposure (PM2.5), outcome (respiratory hospitalization), study design (time-series methodology), and reporting of effect estimates.

This study meets most inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory ED visits (asthma exacerbations) using time-series methodology (quasi-Poisson regression with daily data). However, the abstract does not explicitly report a relative risk, odds ratio, or equivalent effect estimate with confidence interval - only a p-value and EC50 value are mentioned. The study likely reports quantitative effect estimates in the full text, but this cannot be confirmed from the abstract alone. The study design appears to be time-series based on the daily data collection and quasi-Poisson modeling approach.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as an exposure, (3) asthma hospitalization is a respiratory hospitalization outcome, (4) time-stratified case-crossover design is clearly stated, (5) quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs are reported (0.31% increase per 1-μg/m3 PM2.5, 95% CI 0.24-0.37%), and (6) published in English.

This is an original case-crossover study examining PM2.5 (as part of AQI) and respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits for asthma in children. The study reports odds ratios with 95% CIs. Although the primary exposure is AQI, the abstract clearly states PM2.5 was the primary pollutant (62% of days) and that pollutant-specific AQI associations were strongest for PM2.5, making this relevant for PM2.5 exposure assessment. The outcome is respiratory hospitalization/ED visit (asthma exacerbations), meeting inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using a novel statistical approach; (2) Exposure is PM2.5; (3) Outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations (32 respiratory discharge diagnoses); (4) Study design is time-stratified case-crossover; (5) Reports associations (effect estimates) for PM2.5 and respiratory outcomes with statement that 31 of 32 respiratory outcomes were positively associated with PM2.5, implying quantitative estimates were calculated; (6) Published in English. Although cardiovascular outcomes are also included, the study explicitly analyzes respiratory hospitalizations as a major component.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using time-series analysis with DLNM, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures, (3) the outcome is hospital admissions for respiratory disease, (4) the study design is time-series, (5) it reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., RR=1.030, 95% CI: 1.012-1.049 for PM2.5), and (6) it is published in English. Although multiple pollutants were analyzed, PM2.5 is specifically included with quantitative effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures, (3) outcome is respiratory ED presentations and hospitalizations for bronchiolitis, (4) case-crossover design is specified, (5) odds ratios with quantitative estimates are reported (>10% increased risk for PM2.5, >30% for NO2), and (6) published in English. Although multiple pollutants are examined, PM2.5 is specifically included and analyzed.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original time-series epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure (among other pollutants) and respiratory hospitalizations for acute upper respiratory infections in children. It reports relative risk estimates with 95% confidence intervals (RR=1.0247, 95% CI: 1.0092,1.0405 for PM2.5). The study design, exposure, outcome, and quantitative measures all align with the systematic review requirements.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcomes are respiratory hospitalizations and emergency department visits, (4) study design is case-crossover as explicitly stated, (5) multiple odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals are reported, and (6) published in English. Although the study focuses on a specific vulnerable population (childhood cancer survivors), it still examines the fundamental association between PM2.5 and respiratory healthcare encounters that is the focus of the systematic review.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure (among other pollutants), focuses on respiratory hospitalizations (bronchiolitis), and reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals. Bronchiolitis is a respiratory condition requiring hospitalization, which aligns with the outcome of interest.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original case-crossover epidemiological study, (2) examines fine particulate matter (PM2.5) exposure, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalizations in children, (4) case-crossover design, (5) reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., OR=1.004 [0.955-1.056] and stratified estimates), and (6) published in English. Despite examining effect modification by particle constituents, PM2.5 mass concentration is a primary exposure of interest.

While this study meets several inclusion criteria (original epidemiological study, time-series design, PM2.5 exposure, reports RR with statistical significance), the outcome is hospitalization specifically for SARS-CoV-2/COVID-19 infection rather than general respiratory hospitalizations. COVID-19 hospitalizations represent a specific infectious disease outcome rather than the broader category of respiratory hospitalizations typically examined in air pollution studies. The review appears to focus on general respiratory hospitalizations, not disease-specific COVID-19 admissions.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design to examine the association between PM2.5 exposure and asthma emergency department visits. The study reports rate ratios with 95% credible intervals for PM2.5 and other pollutants. Asthma ED visits are a respiratory outcome that qualifies for inclusion.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure, measures respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits as outcomes, reports incidence rate ratios with 95% confidence intervals (1.043 for ED presentations and 1.013 for hospital admissions per 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5), and appears to be published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures, (3) the outcome is respiratory disease hospitalizations, (4) it uses a time-series design with generalized additive models and distributed lag nonlinear models, (5) effect estimates with relative risk increases are reported (8.3% and 12.1% for temperature effects, and positive lag effects for PM2.5 mentioned), and (6) it is published in English. While the abstract does not provide specific PM2.5 effect estimates with confidence intervals, it clearly states there were positive lag effects for PM2.5 on admissions, suggesting quantitative results are reported in the full text.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series analysis with GAM, (2) exposure includes PM2.5 (along with PM10), (3) outcome is respiratory disease hospitalizations, (4) time-series study design is explicitly stated, (5) the results indicate that effect estimates for increased risks were reported (PM2.5 and PM10 were 'associated with increased risks'), and (6) published in English. While the abstract does not explicitly show the numerical effect estimates with confidence intervals, it clearly states associations were found and stratified analyses were performed, which strongly suggests quantitative estimates are reported in the full text.

This is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations (among other cardiorespiratory outcomes). The study reports relative risks with confidence intervals for multiple respiratory diseases including acute respiratory infections, pneumonia, COPD, asthma, and other respiratory diseases. Although the exposure window is medium-term (3-month) rather than acute, it meets all inclusion criteria: original research, PM2.5 exposure, respiratory hospitalization outcome, case-crossover design, and quantitative effect estimates with CIs.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations (URTI). It uses a time-series design (generalized additive Poisson model with daily data), reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CI (0.84% increase per 10 μg/m³, 95% CI: 0.05-1.64%), and examines hospital admissions and emergency room visits. Upper respiratory tract infections are respiratory conditions requiring hospitalization. All inclusion criteria are met.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original time-series epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure (among other pollutants) and respiratory hospitalizations (asthma and COPD admissions). The study reports quantitative effect estimates (risk ratios) with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5. Although the primary finding was for NO2, PM2.5 was explicitly analyzed and results reported, making it eligible for inclusion.

While this study meets most inclusion criteria (PM2.5 exposure, respiratory hospitalization outcome, quantitative effect estimates with CI, original research), it is described as a 'retrospective cohort study' rather than a time-series or case-crossover design. Although distributed lag models were used to analyze daily county-level hospitalization rates (which shares methodological similarities with time-series), the fundamental design is cohort-based tracking individuals over time. The study design does not match the required time-series or case-crossover criteria.

While this is an original epidemiological study using time-series design with PM2.5 exposure and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, the primary outcomes are cardiovascular and cerebrovascular ED visits, not respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits. Although respiratory conditions are mentioned as secondary findings, the study focus and design are centered on cardiovascular/cerebrovascular outcomes, making it inconsistent with the systematic review's specific research question.

This is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design (distributed lag quasi-Poisson models with daily data) examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory ED visits (specifically pneumonia). The study reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals (RR for pneumonia: 1.071, 95% CI: 1.025-1.118 on current day; RR: 1.024, 95% CI: 1.003-1.046 on lag day 1). Although the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes and other pollutants, it meets all inclusion criteria for the respiratory component.

While this study examines PM2.5 exposure and pneumonia hospitalizations (a respiratory outcome) with quantitative effect estimates, it uses a prospective cohort design rather than the required time-series or case-crossover design specified in the inclusion criteria. The study follows 433,032 participants over time to identify incident pneumonia cases, which is characteristic of cohort methodology, not time-series or case-crossover approaches.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It is an original epidemiological study using generalized additive models; (2) Exposure is PM2.5 and source-specific PM2.5; (3) Outcome is respiratory emergency room visits (ERVs); (4) Study design is time-series based on the mention of lag periods and GAM methodology; (5) Reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., RR = 1.011, 95%CI: 1.002, 1.020); (6) Published in English. The study focuses on emergency department visits which aligns with the systematic review criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure includes PM2.5 among other pollutants, (3) outcome is respiratory hospital admissions, (4) case-crossover study design, (5) reports percentage change in odds with 95% CI (equivalent to OR), and (6) published in English. The study specifically reports that a 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5 was associated with 1.2% increase in odds of admission with confidence intervals mentioned.

Although this is an original time-series study with PM2.5 exposure and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is hospitalization for rheumatoid arthritis-associated interstitial lung disease (RA-ILD), which is a specific autoimmune/rheumatologic condition with pulmonary manifestations, not general respiratory hospitalizations. The review targets respiratory hospitalizations (e.g., asthma, COPD, pneumonia, bronchitis), not hospitalizations for autoimmune diseases that happen to affect the lungs.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure, evaluates respiratory ED visits (asthma/wheeze, bronchitis, pneumonia, upper respiratory infections), reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals, and is published in English in a peer-reviewed journal.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-stratified case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure, reports respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits for asthma and COPD as outcomes, provides quantitative effect estimates (excess rates with 95% CI), and appears to be published in English.

While this study meets several inclusion criteria (original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure, time-series design with GAM), the outcome is outpatient visits rather than hospitalizations or ED visits. The title mentions 'hospitalization' but the abstract clearly states the outcome was 'outpatient visits for upper respiratory tract infections,' which does not meet the inclusion criteria for respiratory hospitalization/ED visit outcomes.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using Poisson regression; (2) exposure is PM2.5; (3) outcomes include both respiratory ED visits and hospitalizations; (4) time-series design using daily counts linked to daily PM2.5 estimates; (5) reports multiple RR estimates with 95% CIs for respiratory outcomes (e.g., RR=1.25 [1.21, 1.30] for respiratory EDVs, RR=1.18 [1.10, 1.27] for CLRD); (6) published in English. The study examines both ED visits and hospitalizations for respiratory conditions.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and respiratory hospitalizations for AECOPD. It reports quantitative effect estimates (RR and RERI) with 95% CIs. AECOPD hospitalization is a respiratory hospitalization outcome. While the study focuses on interaction effects with temperature, it still examines the association between PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations, meeting all inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design to investigate the association between PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospital admissions in Kuwait. The study reports quantitative effect estimates (1.61% increase per 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5) with 95% confidence intervals (0.87, 2.35%). The study appears to be published in English and provides appropriate statistical methods including distributed lag models.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using case-crossover design; (2) exposure is source-specific PM2.5; (3) outcomes include respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits for influenza and pneumonia; (4) study design is case-crossover; (5) quantitative effect estimates are reported with 95% CIs (e.g., ER = 9.2%; 95% CI: 4.3%, 14.3%); (6) published in English. Although the study focuses on source-specific PM2.5 rather than total PM2.5, the exposure is explicitly PM2.5 and respiratory infections (influenza and pneumonia) are appropriate respiratory outcomes for hospitalization/ED visits.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure (among other pollutants) and respiratory emergency department visits. It uses generalized additive models with quasi-Poisson regression on daily data, reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs for PM2.5 (5.302% increase, 95% CI: 3.202, 7.445 per 10 µg/m3 increase), and focuses on upper respiratory tract infections requiring ED visits. Although URTI is a specific respiratory condition, it qualifies as a respiratory ED visit outcome.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using generalized additive models; (2) PM2.5 is included as one of the exposures analyzed; (3) Outcome is respiratory hospitalization (pneumonia and asthma); (4) Time-series design indicated by use of generalized additive models with lag structure and daily hospitalization data; (5) Reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (2.22% increase per 10-unit PM2.5 increase, 95%CI: 0.64%, 3.82%); (6) Published in English. While multiple pollutants were analyzed, PM2.5 is specifically included and reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 exposure clearly specified, (3) outcome is asthma emergency room admissions which qualifies as respiratory ED visits, (4) time-series study design explicitly stated, (5) reports percent increase with 95% CI (7.2%, 95% CI: 1.7-13.1%), and (6) published in English. Asthma is a respiratory condition and emergency room admissions are equivalent to ED visits.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly listed as one of the exposures assessed, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (ILD admissions are respiratory hospitalizations), (4) case-crossover design is specified, (5) reports odds ratios with 95% CIs for air pollutants including PM2.5. Although the abstract primarily reports results for SO2 and NO2, PM2.5 was assessed and is clearly stated as one of the exposures analyzed in this multi-pollutant study. Interstitial lung diseases are respiratory conditions requiring hospitalization.

While this is a time-series study that examined PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations with effect estimates, the abstract does not report the specific RR/OR for the PM2.5-respiratory hospitalization association. Only results for NO2, ozone, and noise are presented in the abstract. Without confirmation that PM2.5 results for respiratory outcomes are reported in the full text, this study cannot be confidently included.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure (among other pollutants) and respiratory hospitalizations (COPD admissions). The study uses a time-series design with generalized additive models and distributed lag models. It reports quantitative effect estimates (percent increases in daily admissions) for PM2.5. COPD hospitalizations qualify as respiratory hospitalizations. The study meets all inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) includes PM2.5 as an exposure (along with PM2.5-10), (3) outcome is respiratory hospital admissions, (4) uses case-crossover design, (5) reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (1.73% increase with 95% CI: 1.34%, 2.12% for PM2.5), and (6) published in English. The study also examines multiple respiratory conditions, not just a single outcome.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalizations (pneumonia, acute bronchitis, bronchiolitis, asthma), (4) study design is ecological time-series, (5) reports RR with values at different lags (RR=1.017, 1.022, 1.020), and (6) published in English (with Portuguese translation). The study uses appropriate statistical methods (generalized additive Poisson regression) and controls for relevant confounders.

The study meets most inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospital admissions with quantitative effect estimates (RR with 95% CI). However, the study design is listed as 'difference-in-differences approach' rather than the specifically required time-series or case-crossover design. While difference-in-differences with distributed lag non-linear models shares similarities with time-series analysis and uses daily data across multiple regions and time periods, it is technically a distinct methodological approach. The decision depends on whether the systematic review accepts methodologically related designs or strictly requires traditional time-series or case-crossover studies.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 as one of the exposures, focuses on emergency department visits for respiratory diseases (COPD and upper respiratory diseases), and reports quantitative associations with lag periods. The abstract indicates positive results were found for PM2.5 associations with both COPD and upper respiratory disease ED visits, implying effect estimates are reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalizations (acute lower respiratory infections including pneumonia, COPD exacerbations, etc.), (4) study design is time-series with quasi-Poisson regression, (5) reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., 0.73% increase per 10-μg/m3 PM2.5; 95% CI: 0.40%, 1.06%), and (6) published in English.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure and hospital admissions for multiple disease categories including respiratory diseases. The study reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals (e.g., percentage increase in admissions per 10-μg/m3 increase in PM2.5). Although the study covers multiple organ systems, it explicitly includes respiratory diseases as one of the 7 major disease categories analyzed, making it eligible for inclusion in a systematic review on PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series design with generalized additive model of Poisson regression, (2) examines PM2.5 exposure (along with PM2.5-bound PAHs), (3) outcome is asthma emergency room visits which qualifies as respiratory ED visits, (4) reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for multiple lag periods, and (5) appears to be in English. The study analyzes daily counts of ERVs over multiple years, which is characteristic of time-series design.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using time-series design, (2) Examines PM2.5 exposure (along with PM10), (3) Outcome is respiratory hospitalizations, (4) Time-series study design explicitly stated, (5) Reports percentage change with 95% CI (equivalent to effect estimate), and (6) Published in English. The study provides quantitative effect estimates for PM2.5 and respiratory hospital admissions.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series design with Poisson regression, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed, (3) outcome is asthma-related emergency department visits (AEDv), which are respiratory ED visits, (4) reports relative risks with specific quantitative estimates (4.4% increase per IQR of PM2.5), and (5) appears to be published in English. Although multiple pollutants were analyzed, PM2.5 effect estimates are specifically reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly mentioned as one of the exposures analyzed, (3) outcome is asthma-related hospital admissions and emergency department visits (respiratory hospitalizations), (4) case-crossover design is specified, (5) results mention positive associations with 95% confidence intervals, and (6) published in English. Though multiple pollutants are examined, PM2.5 is specifically analyzed and reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using GAM for time-series analysis; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly examined as an exposure; (3) Respiratory hospitalizations are included as one of the outcomes analyzed; (4) Time-series design using generalized additive model; (5) Reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CI (1.03% increase per 10 μg/m3 PM2.5, 95% CI: 0.50%-1.56% for respiratory HAs); (6) Published in English. While the study examines multiple outcomes beyond respiratory, it clearly includes respiratory hospitalization with specific PM2.5 effect estimates.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 (among other particle metrics) and hospital admissions including respiratory outcomes. While the abstract emphasizes cardiovascular results, it explicitly states that secondary pollutants including PM2.5 were 'more important for respiratory outcomes.' The study uses Poisson regression time-series analysis and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals. It examines emergency hospital admissions which meets the outcome criteria.

This is an original time-series study using GAMs to assess short-term effects of PM2.5 (among other pollutants) on cause-specific hospitalizations including respiratory system diseases. The study reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., NO2 effect on respiratory: 1.36%, 95%CI: 0.74-1.98%). While it examines multiple disease categories, it includes respiratory hospitalizations as one of the outcomes with specific effect estimates, meeting all inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure to PM2.5 (and PM10), (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization and ED visits for asthma exacerbations, (4) time-series study design using Poisson regression, (5) reports relative risk with 95% CI for PM2.5 and respiratory outcomes, and (6) published in English. Asthma exacerbation hospitalizations and ED visits are respiratory outcomes relevant to the review.

While this is a time-series study examining respiratory ED visits with effect estimates reported, and PM2.5 was included as a covariate in the models, the primary exposures of interest are precipitation and temperature on thunderstorm days, not PM2.5. The results explicitly state that PM2.5 was not significantly associated with asthma ED visits on thunderstorm days, and PM2.5 appears to have been controlled for as a confounder rather than analyzed as a main exposure. The study does not report effect estimates for PM2.5 as a primary exposure.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using time-series analysis with generalized additive models, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures, (3) the outcome is respiratory hospitalizations (acute lower respiratory tract infections including pneumonia and bronchitis), (4) it uses a time-series study design, (5) it reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 (e.g., RR=1.0064, 95% CI 1.0004-1.0124 for pneumonia), and (6) the abstract is in English. Although multiple pollutants are studied, PM2.5 is specifically included with separate effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure includes PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalizations (asthma and COPD), (4) uses case-crossover design, (5) reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals, and (6) published in English. While it also examines PM10, PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures.

This is an original epidemiological study that examines PM2.5 exposure (among other exposures) and respiratory hospital admissions. It uses a time-series design with daily counts analyzed using Poisson regression models. The study reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals for the association between PM2.5 and respiratory admissions (7.5% increase, 95% CI: 4.9-10.2% per 12.4 μg/m3 increase). All inclusion criteria are met.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory hospital admissions, (4) time-series design explicitly stated, (5) reports quantitative effect estimates with percent increases in hospitalization rates per 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5 (overall 4.1%, Black 8.6%, White 6.2%), and (6) published in English. No exclusion criteria apply.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-stratified case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure, reports respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome, provides quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (1.74% increase, 95% CI: 1.41-2.07% per 10-μg/m3 increase in PM2.5), and appears to be published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure, reports respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome with quantitative effect estimates (1.95% increase with 95% CI for respiratory diseases per 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5), and appears to be published in English.

While this is a time-series study examining respiratory hospitalizations with effect estimates, the primary exposure is particle oxidative potential (OP), not PM2.5 mass concentration itself. The study focuses on OP(AA) and OP(GSH) as the exposure measures rather than PM2.5 concentration, which does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring PM2.5 as the exposure of interest.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 (fine particulate matter) exposure and emergency department visits for pediatric asthma. It uses a time-series design (daily data with Poisson GLM), reports rate ratios with 95% confidence intervals, and meets all inclusion criteria. The source apportionment approach is a method of analyzing PM2.5 components, not a different exposure.

This is an original epidemiological study using GAM (consistent with time-series design) to examine PM2.5 exposure and respiratory disease hospitalization. It reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals (1.95% increase per 10 μg/m3 PM2.5, 95% CI: 0.25, 3.67). Meets all inclusion criteria: original research, PM2.5 exposure, respiratory hospitalization outcome, time-series design, and reports effect estimates with CIs.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations (specifically asthma and cause-specific respiratory diseases mentioned), (4) study design is explicitly stated as time-series, (5) reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., RR 1.16, 95% CI 1.00 to 1.35 for asthma), and (6) published in English. Although the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes, it clearly includes respiratory hospitalizations as a primary outcome.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using time-series analysis; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly examined as one of the exposures; (3) the outcome is chronic respiratory disease (CRD) hospitalizations; (4) study design is time-series; (5) quantitative effect estimates are reported as excess risks with 95% CIs (2.13% increase, 95% CI: 0.55%, 3.74% for PM2.5); and (6) published in English. The study specifically reports PM2.5 effects separately from other pollutants.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5/fine particulate matter, (3) outcome is respiratory healthcare visits which includes hospitalizations and ED visits, (4) uses case-crossover study design (time-stratified), (5) reports odds ratios with effect estimates (increased odds mentioned for all three respiratory categories), and (6) published in English. The study examines effect modification by temperature but PM2.5 remains the primary exposure of interest.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly examined as one of the exposures, (3) the outcome is respiratory disease hospitalization in children, (4) the study design is clearly stated as a time-stratified case-crossover design, (5) quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals are reported (OR=1.017, 95%CI: 1.003-1.031 for PM2.5), and (6) the article is published in English.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 (among other exposures) in relation to respiratory outcomes including ED visits and inpatient hospitalizations for asthma exacerbation. The study reports rate ratios with confidence intervals. Although the focus is on effect modification by viral infections and the abstract primarily reports results for grass pollen, the study explicitly includes PM2.5 as an exposure and ED/inpatient visits as outcomes, which meet the inclusion criteria.

This is an original epidemiological study using a generalized additive model (GAM) on daily data, which is characteristic of a time-series design. The study examines PM2.5 as one of multiple air pollutants and reports quantitative effect estimates (percentage increases with 95% CIs) for respiratory hospitalizations, albeit in a specific subpopulation (patients with diabetes mellitus and comorbid respiratory diseases). While the outcome is limited to a specific patient subgroup, it still represents respiratory hospitalizations and meets the inclusion criteria.

While this study meets most inclusion criteria (original epidemiological study, time-series design, includes PM2.5 exposure, reports RR with CI), the outcome is acute upper respiratory tract infections (AURTIs) which are typically minor infections affecting the nose, throat, and sinuses. The systematic review specifically targets respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits, which generally refer to more severe lower respiratory conditions (pneumonia, COPD exacerbations, asthma attacks) rather than upper respiratory infections. AURTIs typically represent less severe conditions that may not require hospitalization.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure and emergency department visits for asthma (a respiratory outcome). The study reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals. It meets all inclusion criteria: original epidemiological research, PM2.5 exposure, respiratory ED visits as outcome, time-series design with generalized additive models, and effect estimates with CIs reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study analyzing data from Korean communities; (2) exposure is PM2.5; (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations; (4) study design is case time series analysis (a variant of time-series); (5) reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CI (1.43% increase, 95% CI: 1.34%, 1.52% for respiratory hospitalizations per 10 μg/m³ PM2.5 increment); (6) published in English. Although the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes, it includes respiratory hospitalizations as a primary outcome of interest.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, evaluates PM2.5 exposure, examines respiratory hospitalizations (COPD), and reports a quantitative effect estimate (1.6% increase, 95% CI: 0.6%, 2.7%) per 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5. The study is published in English and provides clear effect measures with confidence intervals.

While this study examines PM2.5 among other pollutants, uses a case-crossover design, and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is 'pediatric asthma visit treated with prednisone' which appears to be outpatient visits requiring prednisone treatment rather than specifically hospitalizations or ED visits. The abstract mentions 'hospital visits' in the introduction but the actual outcome measured is 'pediatric asthma visit' which is ambiguous. The results explicitly state 'no such associations with fine particles (≤2.5μm)' indicating no significant PM2.5 effect was found. The primary focus is on ultrafine particles, not PM2.5.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed, (3) the outcome is respiratory hospital admissions, (4) the study design is case-crossover (time-stratified), (5) the abstract indicates effect estimates were computed showing associations between pollutants and admissions, and (6) the article appears to be in English. Although multiple pollutants were examined, PM2.5 is specifically analyzed and the abstract mentions quantitative associations were found.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure, assesses respiratory hospitalizations (COPD), and reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals. The study compares different exposure metrics but PM2.5 is the primary exposure of interest.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using case-crossover design as stated in title; (2) PM2.5 exposure is examined; (3) Respiratory hospitalizations are reported as one of the outcomes (916,388 respiratory admissions); (4) Case-crossover design with conditional logistic regression; (5) Quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs are provided (0.26% increase, 95% CI = 0.22%, 0.31% for respiratory admissions per 10 μg/m³ increase in PM2.5); (6) Published in English. The study examines multiple outcomes but respiratory hospitalization is specifically analyzed.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using quasi-Poisson regression with distributed lag model; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as an exposure; (3) outcome is respiratory hospital admissions (asthma, COPD, bronchiectasis); (4) time-series design with data from 2008-2018 analyzing short-term effects; (5) reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 (asthma: RR=1.004, 95% CI: 1.002-1.007; COPD: RR=1.003, 95% CI: 1.001-1.005); (6) published in English. Although multiple pollutants are analyzed, PM2.5 results are specifically reported for respiratory hospitalizations.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure, reports respiratory hospitalizations (pneumonia) as the outcome, and provides quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (12% and 4% increases in admissions).

The study focuses on coarse particles (PM2.5-10) as the primary exposure, not PM2.5. While PM2.5 is mentioned as a confounder that was adjusted for, the exposure of interest is coarse particles. This does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring PM2.5 as the exposure.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using GAM time-series analysis; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed; (3) the outcome is hospital admissions for asthma, which is a respiratory hospitalization; (4) the study design is time-series; (5) relative risk estimates with 95% confidence intervals are reported for PM2.5 (RR=1.015, 95% CI: 1.003-1.028 per 10 μg/m3 increase); and (6) the article appears to be published in English. Although the study examines multiple air pollutants, PM2.5 is specifically analyzed and reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) includes PM2.5 exposure analysis, (3) outcomes are respiratory ED visits and hospitalizations for COPD exacerbation, (4) uses time-series design with Poisson regression, (5) reports relative risks with specific values (e.g., RR 1.08-1.11 for PM2.5), and (6) published in English. COPD exacerbation is a respiratory condition requiring hospitalization/ED visit.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using time-series design, examines PM2.5 exposure (among other pollutants), reports respiratory emergency department visits as the outcome, and provides rate ratios with 95% credible intervals for PM2.5 effects. The study is published in English and reports quantitative effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure (source-specific components), reports respiratory emergency department visits as an outcome, and provides quantitative effect estimates (excess risk percentages) with 95% confidence intervals. The study explicitly reports associations for respiratory EDVs including asthma subclass.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using time-series analysis; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly mentioned as one of the exposures analyzed; (3) the outcome is asthma hospitalizations, which is a respiratory hospitalization; (4) the study design is time-series; (5) the abstract mentions that effects and attributable risks were calculated for pollutants including PM2.5, indicating quantitative effect estimates were reported; (6) the article appears to be published in English. Although multiple pollutants were examined, PM2.5 is specifically mentioned in the results as being associated with the heaviest burden in heating season.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using time-series regression with DLNM; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures; (3) the outcome is hospital admissions for respiratory diseases; (4) the study design is time-series; (5) it reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals (RR 1.089, 95% CI 1.001-1.183 for PM2.5); (6) the abstract is in English. Although multiple pollutants were analyzed, PM2.5 results are clearly reported with quantitative effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a multi-city time-series design; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures examined; (3) the outcome is hospital admissions for acute bronchitis, which is a respiratory hospitalization; (4) the study design is time-series using generalized additive models; (5) quantitative effect estimates are reported with 95% confidence intervals (1.23% increase per 10 µg/m3 PM2.5 increase with 95% CI 0.21-2.26%); and (6) the article is published in English. Acute bronchitis is a respiratory condition that requires hospitalization, meeting the respiratory hospitalization outcome criterion.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using time-series design, includes PM2.5 as one of the exposures assessed, examines asthma emergency department visits (respiratory ED visits) as the outcome, reports rate ratios (RRs) with confidence intervals, and appears to be published in English. Although multiple pollutants are analyzed, PM2.5 is explicitly included.

While the study includes PM2.5 (fine particulate matter) as an exposure variable and respiratory hospitalizations as the outcome, the abstract only reports effect estimates for temperature (18% increase in risk for 4°C temperature increase), not for PM2.5. The study appears to be primarily focused on temperature effects. Without a quantitative effect estimate specifically for PM2.5 reported in the abstract, the study does not meet inclusion criteria requiring a reported RR/OR for PM2.5.

This is an original time-series study examining both PM2.5 and ozone exposure in relation to cardiorespiratory outcomes including respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits. The study reports quantitative risk ratios with specific values mentioned for respiratory disease and asthma/wheeze outcomes. While the primary aim is methodological comparison of visit types, it meets all inclusion criteria as it presents original epidemiological analyses with PM2.5 exposure, respiratory outcomes (ED and hospital admissions), time-series design, and effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using a case time series design, (2) PM2.5 exposure explicitly stated, (3) Outcomes include both respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits, (4) Time-series study design (case time series is a variant of time-series analysis), (5) Reports excess relative risk with 95% confidence intervals for respiratory outcomes (ERR 1.34% for respiratory ED visits), and (6) Published in English. The study examines multiple outcomes but includes respiratory hospitalization/ED visits as specified outcomes.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design that examines PM2.5 exposure (among other pollutants) and respiratory hospitalizations (COPD exacerbations requiring hospitalization). The study reports rate ratios with 95% CIs for PM2.5 (RR=1.030, 95% CI: 1.006-1.055 per 10 μg/m3). The abstract is in English and the study design is explicitly stated as case-crossover with time-series analysis.

This is an original time-series epidemiological study examining the association between PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospital admissions (among other outcomes). The study analyzes source-apportioned PM2.5, uses generalized linear models appropriate for time-series analysis, examines respiratory and cardiovascular hospital admissions in Medicare patients, and reports quantitative associations. The abstract indicates significant associations were found and effect estimates were calculated using distributed-lag models, suggesting relative risks or similar measures were reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using generalized additive models with distributed lag models, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed, (3) outcome is pediatric asthma emergency department visits which qualifies as respiratory ED visits, (4) study design is time-series based on daily ED visits and pollutant concentrations, (5) reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals (RR=1.011, 95%CI: 1.002-1.021 for PM2.5), and (6) published in English. Although multiple pollutants are analyzed, PM2.5 is specifically reported with effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series analysis with case-crossover design as indicated in title; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as an exposure; (3) asthma hospitalizations are respiratory hospitalizations; (4) study design is time-series; (5) reports rate ratios with 95% CI for PM2.5 (RR=1.014, 95%CI: 1.000-1.028 per 10 µg/m3); (6) published in English. Despite the title mentioning case-crossover, the abstract describes time-series analysis, which is an acceptable design.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using time-series regression analysis, (2) PM2.5 is one of the exposures analyzed, (3) the outcome is respiratory hospitalization (ALRI including pneumonia and bronchiolitis), (4) the study design is time-series, (5) quantitative effect estimates are reported as relative risks with 95% confidence intervals (RR=1.089, 95%CI:1.075-1.103 for PM2.5), and (6) the abstract is in English. While multiple pollutants are analyzed, PM2.5 is explicitly included with its own effect estimate.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and cardiopulmonary hospitalizations (including respiratory outcomes like asthma). The study uses Poisson regression with time-series analysis approach, examining associations by lag days with adjustment for temporal confounders. Effect estimates are reported as percentage increases with 95% confidence intervals. The study meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure (among other pollutants) and respiratory emergency room admissions in children. Although the abstract states PM2.5 was not significantly associated with ER admissions, the study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using time-series methodology with Poisson regression, examines PM2.5 exposure explicitly, assesses respiratory ER visits as the outcome, and reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals. The fact that PM2.5 showed null results does not warrant exclusion, as the exposure was analyzed and results were reported.

While this is an interrupted time series study that uses PM2.5 exposure estimates and examines respiratory hospitalizations among other outcomes, it is a long-term effects study examining impacts over 8 years following a coalmine fire event. This does not align with the typical time-series or case-crossover designs that examine short-term associations between daily/weekly PM2.5 fluctuations and respiratory outcomes. The study design is interrupted time series focused on a single disaster event rather than ongoing air pollution exposure patterns. Additionally, the abstract does not clearly indicate whether condition-specific effect estimates with confidence intervals are reported for respiratory hospitalizations specifically.

This is an original 18-year time-series study examining PM2.5 (specifically organic carbon fraction of PM2.5) exposure and respiratory-related emergency department visits in children. The study reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., 4% and 8% increases for URI and pneumonia respectively). Although multiple pollutants were examined, PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures. The outcome is respiratory ED visits (bronchitis, bronchiolitis, pneumonia, URI), which meets inclusion criteria. All major inclusion criteria are satisfied.

The study examines hospitalizations for pulmonary embolism and venous thrombosis, which are cardiovascular/thromboembolic conditions, not respiratory diseases. Additionally, the exposure is PM10, not PM2.5. The outcome does not meet the inclusion criteria for respiratory hospitalization.

The study examines the association between PM exposure and suicide deaths, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. The outcome does not meet inclusion criteria despite having an appropriate time-series study design and quantitative effect estimates. Additionally, the primary exposure analyzed is PM10, not PM2.5.

This is a critical review of PM10-mortality time-series studies, not an original epidemiological study. It fails multiple inclusion criteria: (1) it is a review rather than original research, (2) the exposure is PM10 not PM2.5, and (3) the outcome is mortality not respiratory hospitalization/ED visit.

This is a systematic review/meta-analysis of existing studies, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is coronary/cardiovascular disease, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. The exposure includes PM10 but not specifically PM2.5.

This is a meta-analysis/systematic review, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. The exposure is PM10, not PM2.5.

While this is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design with PM2.5 exposure and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is out-of-hospital cardiac arrest of cardiac origin, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visit. The study focuses on cardiovascular outcomes, not respiratory outcomes, which is the focus of this systematic review.

This is an animal experimental study conducted in mice, not an epidemiological study in humans. The study examines molecular mechanisms of PM2.5-induced lung injury through controlled laboratory exposure, rather than examining the association between environmental PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits in human populations. It does not use time-series or case-crossover design, and does not report RR/OR for respiratory hospitalizations.

This is explicitly stated to be a review article ('this review is focused on these aspects') rather than an original epidemiological study. It discusses various aspects of particulate matter and lung diseases but does not present original research data or quantitative effect estimates from a single study.

The study examines PM10 (particulate matter ≤10 μm), not PM2.5 (≤2.5 μm) as required by the inclusion criteria. While the outcome (respiratory hospitalizations for COPD and asthma) and study design (time-series) meet the criteria, the exposure measure does not match the systematic review's focus on PM2.5.

Although this study includes a multisite time-series analysis component with PM2.5 exposure, the primary outcome reported is cardiovascular hospital admissions, not respiratory hospitalizations. The abstract specifically mentions 'cardiovascular hospital admissions' as the key finding, with no mention of respiratory outcomes. This fails to meet inclusion criterion #3.

The study examines PM10 (particulate matter ≤10 μm), not PM2.5 (≤2.5 μm) as required by the inclusion criteria. While the study is an original epidemiological study with time-series design using Poisson regression, reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, and includes respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome, the exposure measure does not meet the specified criteria for PM2.5.

Although this is an original case-crossover study examining respiratory hospitalizations with quantitative effect estimates, the exposure is PM10 (particles ≤10 μm) rather than PM2.5 (particles ≤2.5 μm). The abstract explicitly states PM10 and NO2 were analyzed, with no mention of PM2.5 as an exposure variable.

While this is an original time-series study examining respiratory hospitalizations with quantitative effect estimates (RR with 95% CI), the exposure is PM10 (particles ≤10 μm), not PM2.5 (particles ≤2.5 μm). The inclusion criteria specifically require PM2.5 or fine particulate matter ≤2.5 μm as the exposure. PM10 includes larger particles and is a different exposure measure that does not meet the systematic review requirements.

This study is a health impact assessment/policy analysis that estimates avoidable hospitalizations based on relative risks obtained from a literature review, rather than an original epidemiological study that directly analyzes the association between PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations. While it mentions 'time series studies' in the abstract, the paper itself appears to be using existing relative risks from other studies to calculate potential health gains from policy changes, not conducting an original time-series analysis.

The study examines PM10 (particles <10 µm), not PM2.5 (≤2.5 µm), which fails the exposure criterion. Additionally, the outcome is emergency ambulance dispatches rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. While respiratory diseases are mentioned, the primary outcome and reported effect estimates are for ambulance dispatches broadly, not specifically respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits.

Although this is an original epidemiological study with case-crossover design examining PM2.5 exposure and reporting effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is ischemic stroke hospitalization, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit. This fails to meet the primary outcome inclusion criteria.

The study examines cardiovascular events (CVE) as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Additionally, the exposure is PM10, not PM2.5. The study fails to meet both the exposure and outcome inclusion criteria.

The study examines cardiovascular mortality as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. The exposure includes PM10 but not PM2.5 specifically. The outcome does not meet the inclusion criteria which specifically requires respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original epidemiological studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. Additionally, the outcome is mortality (all-cause, cardiovascular, respiratory, and cerebrovascular mortality), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits as required by the inclusion criteria.

This is a review/book chapter that summarizes existing literature rather than an original epidemiological study. The outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. It does not report original quantitative effect estimates.

Although this is an original case-crossover study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is myocardial infarction (MI) mortality, which is a cardiovascular outcome, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit. This does not meet the inclusion criteria for a systematic review on respiratory hospitalizations.

Although this is an original case-crossover study that includes PM2.5 as one of the exposures and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is stroke hospitalization, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. This does not meet the inclusion criteria for a systematic review on PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations.

The study examines exposure to PM10 (coarse particulate matter) from Saharan dust, not PM2.5 (fine particulate matter ≤2.5 µm). The outcome is respiratory symptoms (cough) rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Although it uses an appropriate case-crossover design, it does not meet the inclusion criteria for exposure type or outcome measure.

While this is an original time-series study examining respiratory hospital visits with effect estimates, the exposure is PM10 (not PM2.5). The study evaluates the effect of a burning ban intervention on air pollution and health outcomes, measuring PM10 concentrations rather than PM2.5. PM2.5 is not mentioned in the abstract as an exposure or co-exposure.

The study examines coarse particulate matter (PM10-2.5) exposure and ischemic stroke hospitalizations. This does not meet inclusion criteria as the outcome is cardiovascular (stroke), not respiratory hospitalization/ED visit. Additionally, while PM2.5 is mentioned as an adjustment variable, the primary exposure is PM10-2.5 (coarse particulate matter), not PM2.5.

Although this is an original time-series study that includes PM2.5 exposure and reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is mortality rather than hospitalization or emergency department visits. The study examines cause-specific mortality including respiratory mortality, but does not assess respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits, which is the required outcome for this systematic review.

This is a systematic literature review/meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. It reviews 34 other articles examining climate factors and lower respiratory tract infections. The inclusion criteria specifically exclude reviews and meta-analyses.
Study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) as the exposure and respiratory mortality (not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits) as the outcome. Both the exposure and outcome fail to meet inclusion criteria.
Study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) exposure and respiratory mortality (not hospitalization/ED visits). Fails to meet inclusion criteria for both exposure type and outcome.

The study examines PM10 (particulate matter ≤10 µm) rather than PM2.5 (≤2.5 µm) as the exposure. Additionally, the outcome is years of life lost (YLL) due to respiratory disease mortality, not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. The study does not meet the inclusion criteria for either exposure or outcome.

This is a meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The first inclusion criterion requires original epidemiological studies, and the exclusion criteria explicitly exclude reviews and meta-analyses. While it examines PM2.5 exposure and includes respiratory outcomes, it synthesizes data from 152 other studies rather than reporting original research.

While this is an original epidemiological study examining respiratory hospitalizations with appropriate study designs (Poisson regression/time-series and case-crossover) and quantitative effect estimates, the exposure is PM10 (≤10µm), not PM2.5 (≤2.5µm). The study only examines PM10 and NO2, without analyzing PM2.5 as required by the inclusion criteria.

The study examines PM10 (particulate matter <10 μm), not PM2.5 (≤2.5 μm) as required by inclusion criteria. Additionally, the outcome is mortality rather than hospitalization or emergency department visits. While it uses an appropriate case-crossover design and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, it fails to meet two critical inclusion criteria regarding exposure (PM2.5) and outcome (respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).

The study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) exposure and mortality (not hospitalizations or ED visits) as the outcome. It fails to meet both the exposure criterion (PM2.5) and outcome criterion (respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).

This study examines PM10, NO2, and SO2 as exposures but does not analyze PM2.5. The outcome is respiratory disease mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. Both the exposure and outcome do not meet the inclusion criteria.

This study examines coarse particulate matter (PM2.5-10), not PM2.5 as the primary exposure. Additionally, the outcome is mortality rather than respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. While the study design is time-series and quantitative effect estimates are reported, it fails to meet the key inclusion criteria for exposure (PM2.5) and outcome (respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).

Study examines PM10 exposure (not PM2.5) and mortality outcomes (not hospitalization or ED visits). The outcome is respiratory deaths, not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits as required by inclusion criteria.

This study examines PM10 exposure (not PM2.5) and respiratory mortality (not hospitalization or ED visits). The outcome is death, which does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits.

This study examines mortality as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. Additionally, the primary exposure metrics are particle number concentration (PNC) and particle surface area concentration (PSC), not PM2.5 mass concentration. While PM10 is mentioned as a comparison pollutant, PM2.5 is not included as an exposure measure.

The study examines mortality as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Additionally, the exposure is PM10 (not PM2.5), NO2, and O3. Both the outcome and primary exposure do not meet inclusion criteria.
The study examines PM10 exposure, not PM2.5, and the outcome is respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. Both the exposure and outcome do not meet the inclusion criteria.

This study fails to meet multiple inclusion criteria: (1) The exposure is PM10, not PM2.5; (2) The outcome is coronary heart disease hospitalization (cardiovascular), not respiratory hospitalization. The study does not examine respiratory outcomes at all.

The outcome is mortality (all-cause, cardiovascular, and respiratory mortality), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The study examines economic losses due to mortality rather than hospital admissions. Although it uses a time-series design and examines PM2.5 exposure, it does not meet the outcome criterion.

The study examines coarse particulate matter (PM2.5-10, not PM2.5) as the primary exposure, and the outcome is respiratory mortality rather than respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. While it uses a time-series design and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, it does not meet the inclusion criteria for exposure type or outcome.

While this is an original epidemiological study with PM2.5 exposure and case-crossover design that reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is mortality (all-cause, cardiovascular, respiratory/thoracic cancer) rather than respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The study does not meet the outcome inclusion criteria.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. Fails inclusion criteria 1 and 3.

While this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is mortality (deaths), not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. The study examines years of life lost and mortality counts from various causes including respiratory diseases, but does not assess hospital admissions or ED visits.

While this is an original epidemiological study using case-crossover design with PM2.5 exposure and quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is mortality (all-cause and specific-cause mortality including respiratory-related mortality), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The inclusion criteria specifically require respiratory hospitalization/ED visits as the outcome.

The outcome is mortality (all-cause mortality in elderly aged 65+), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visit. Although the study meets other criteria (original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure, time-series and case-crossover designs, reports effect estimates), the outcome does not match the inclusion criteria for this systematic review.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original epidemiological studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. The abstract clearly states 'We conducted a rapid systematic review and meta-analysis following PRISMA guidelines' and describes screening 163 articles and extracting data from 14 eligible studies.

While this study meets several inclusion criteria (original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure, case-crossover design, reports effect estimates with CI), the outcome is respiratory MORTALITY, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit as required by the inclusion criteria. The study focuses on deaths rather than hospital admissions.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. It synthesizes results from 33 other studies. Additionally, the outcome is mortality (not hospitalization or ED visits), which does not meet the inclusion criteria for respiratory hospitalization outcomes.

While this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is mortality (deaths) rather than respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. The study specifically examines 'increased risk of death' including respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospital admissions.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original epidemiological studies and explicitly exclude reviews and meta-analyses.

Although this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates and confidence intervals, the outcome is respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits as required by the inclusion criteria.

While this study meets several inclusion criteria (original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure, time-series design, reports effect estimates with CIs), the outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The study examines respiratory mortality rather than respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits, which does not meet the specified outcome criterion.

This is a summary of an integrated research program (NPACT Initiative) consisting of four complementary studies including time-series epidemiology, toxicological animal studies, and in-vitro studies. While it includes PM2.5 exposure and mentions a time-series study (Ito study) of morbidity, the outcomes described are general 'mortality and morbidity' rather than specifically respiratory hospitalizations. The abstract does not specify respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits as outcomes, nor does it provide specific effect estimates with confidence intervals. Additionally, this appears to be a program overview/summary rather than a single original epidemiological study, and includes substantial animal and in-vitro components.

This is a methodological comparison study (meta-analysis vs pooled analysis) rather than an original epidemiological study. While it uses time-series data and includes PM2.5 as an exposure, the outcome is respiratory mortality (deaths), not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. The study does not report original effect estimates for respiratory hospitalizations.

Study examines ozone exposure (not PM2.5) as the primary exposure and mortality (not hospitalization/ED visit) as the outcome. While the abstract mentions that results were independent of fine particulate matter, PM2.5 is only analyzed as a confounder, not the main exposure of interest. The outcome is respiratory mortality rather than respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits.

Although this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with effect estimates, the outcome is respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits as required by the inclusion criteria.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis (not an original epidemiological study), and the outcome is heart failure hospitalization/incidence/mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. Fails inclusion criteria 1 and 3.

This is explicitly identified as a review article (last sentence states 'have been described in this review'). The abstract describes general mechanisms and global burden of PM2.5 rather than presenting original epidemiological research with quantitative effect estimates. Does not meet inclusion criterion #1 requiring an original epidemiological study.

This is explicitly stated as a review article ('In this review, we synthesize the scientific evidence...'), not an original epidemiological study. Reviews are listed in the exclusion criteria. Additionally, the outcomes described include birth outcomes, respiratory impacts, immune status, brain development, and cardiometabolic health - not specifically respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.

This is a scoping review, not an original epidemiological study. It meets exclusion criteria as a review article. Additionally, the outcomes are neurologic diseases (stroke, dementia, Parkinson disease, MS) rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. Exclusion criterion specifically states 'Reviews, meta-analyses, editorials, or commentaries' should be excluded. The abstract clearly states 'This review aimed to systematically summarize the epidemiological literature' and describes pooling effect estimates from 145 studies.

This is explicitly a review article (stated as 'This present review') focusing on biological mechanisms of PM2.5-induced cell death, not an original epidemiological study. It does not examine respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits, does not use time-series or case-crossover design, and does not report quantitative effect estimates for clinical outcomes.

This is a meta-analysis (not an original epidemiological study) examining the association between PM2.5 and myocardial infarction (MI), which is a cardiovascular outcome, not a respiratory hospitalization or ED visit. Fails inclusion criteria 1 (study type) and 3 (outcome).

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria explicitly require original epidemiological studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. Although it includes PM2.5 exposure and mentions hospital utilization as an outcome, it does not meet the fundamental requirement of being an original study.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original epidemiological studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. Although the paper examines PM2.5 constituents and includes respiratory morbidity as an outcome, it synthesizes data from 67 other articles rather than presenting original research findings.

This is explicitly described as a review article ('The current review investigate epidemiological and experimental findings from 2016 to 2021'), not an original epidemiological study. Reviews are explicitly excluded from the inclusion criteria.

This is a review article (explicitly stated as 'this review article was prepared') focusing on PM2.5 and chronic kidney disease, not respiratory hospitalizations. It fails multiple inclusion criteria: (1) it is a review, not an original epidemiological study, and (2) the outcome is kidney disease, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria explicitly require original studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. Additionally, the outcomes reported are mortality (respiratory and cardiovascular deaths), not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits.
This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses.

This is explicitly identified as a review article ('In this review, we discussed...'), which does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring original epidemiological studies. Reviews are specifically listed in the exclusion criteria.

This study examines mortality as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Additionally, the study design is a cohort study examining long-term exposure, not a time-series or case-crossover design as required by the inclusion criteria.

This appears to be a narrative review, commentary, or editorial discussing the general health effects of wildfire smoke and PM2.5. It does not describe an original epidemiological study with specific methods, population, or quantitative effect estimates. The text discusses general concepts, protective measures, and knowledge gaps rather than presenting original research findings.

This is a review article (as explicitly stated in the abstract: 'In this review, we summarize...') that examines the toxicity of PM2.5 to vascular endothelial cells. It does not meet inclusion criteria because: (1) it is a review, not an original epidemiological study, (2) the outcome is vascular endothelial cell damage/dysfunction, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits, and (3) no quantitative effect estimates (RR, OR, CI) are mentioned.

This is a rapid review/systematic review that synthesizes evidence from other studies (found 450 manuscripts, 15 met inclusion criteria). It is not an original epidemiological study. Reviews are explicitly excluded per the exclusion criteria.

This is a meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is respiratory disease mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits as required by the inclusion criteria.

This is explicitly a review article as stated in the title ('A review of implications for human health'). It does not present original epidemiological research, does not report primary data on respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits, and does not provide quantitative effect estimates (RR, OR, etc.) from an original study. It fails multiple inclusion criteria.

This is a review article (as stated in the abstract: 'This review summarizes and discusses studies') examining the relationship between PM2.5 and neurological outcomes (Alzheimer's disease and dementia), not respiratory hospitalizations. It fails multiple inclusion criteria: it is not an original epidemiological study, the outcome is neurological rather than respiratory hospitalization/ED visits, and it is explicitly a review rather than a primary study.

This is a meta-analysis (not an original epidemiological study) examining the association between PM and myocardial infarction hospitalization/mortality (cardiovascular outcome, not respiratory outcome). Fails inclusion criteria #1 (not an original study) and #3 (wrong outcome).

This is a systematic review (not an original epidemiological study) that examines ocular surface diseases (conjunctivitis, dry eye, blepharitis) rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. It fails to meet multiple inclusion criteria.

This is a review article (explicitly states 'In this review') focused on cardiovascular effects and vascular smooth muscle cells, not respiratory hospitalizations. It does not meet inclusion criteria for being an original epidemiological study with respiratory hospitalization outcomes.

This article focuses on cancer outcomes (cancer risk and cancer mortality) rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Additionally, the article appears to be a narrative review or commentary ('explores', 'examines', 'concludes by proposing strategies') rather than an original epidemiological study. The study design does not match time-series or case-crossover criteria.

This is explicitly a review article (stated in title and abstract), not an original epidemiological study. The outcome is cardiac developmental toxicity/congenital heart defects, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. Multiple exclusion criteria are met.

This is explicitly stated to be a review article of in vitro and in vivo experimental studies, not an original epidemiological study. It does not employ time-series or case-crossover design, does not focus on respiratory hospitalization/ED visits as outcomes, and does not report quantitative effect estimates (RR/OR) from epidemiological analysis.

This is explicitly stated as a review article ('This review aims to summarize and discuss...'), not an original epidemiological study.
